title: Foundations & Measurement
expanded_description: Adding vectors is different from adding ordinary numbers because direction matters. When combining vectors, we must account for both magnitude and direction. The result of adding two or more vectors is a single vector called the resultant, which has the same effect as all the original vectors combined. Vector addition is essential in physics for finding net displacement, net force, net velocity, and more.

core_concept.principle: Vectors are added geometrically by connecting them tip-to-tail or by constructing a parallelogram. The resultant vector represents the combined effect.
core_concept.explanation: Imagine walking 3 m east, then 4 m north. You don't end up 7 m away—you end up 5 m northeast. Adding vectors must account for direction. The tip-to-tail method visually shows how vectors combine: place the tail of the second at the tip of the first; the resultant runs from the first tail to the last tip. Mathematically, for perpendicular vectors, the Pythagorean theorem gives magnitude, and trigonometry gives direction.

image.alt: Diagram showing two vectors added tip-to-tail to form resultant
image.caption: Vector addition combines magnitude and direction to produce a resultant.

sections.introduction: The tip-to-tail method is a visual way to add vectors. It works for any number of vectors in any orientation.

key_concept.definition: To add vectors graphically using the tip-to-tail method, draw the first vector to scale, then draw the next vector starting at the tip of the first, maintaining its correct direction and scale. Continue for all vectors. The resultant is the vector drawn from the tail of the first to the tip of the last.
key_concept.context: This method emphasizes that the order of addition does not matter—vectors are commutative. It is especially useful for understanding the geometry of vector combinations.

principles.statement: Each vector must be drawn to the same scale, with its length proportional to its magnitude, and its arrow pointing in the correct direction.
principles.application: Choose a scale (e.g., 1 cm = 5 m) so that all vectors fit on the page.
principles.example: For a 20 m displacement east, draw a 4 cm arrow east if scale is 1 cm = 5 m.

principles.statement: The resultant vector $\vec{R} = \vec{A} + \vec{B}$ is drawn from the tail of $\vec{A}$ to the tip of $\vec{B}$.
principles.application: Measure its length and direction with a ruler and protractor, then convert back using the scale.
principles.example: If the resultant measures 5 cm at 37°, and scale is 1 cm = 5 m, then $\vec{R}$ has magnitude 25 m at 37°.

process_flow.description: Decide on a scale that allows all vectors to be drawn clearly (e.g., 1 cm = 10 N).
Draw an arrow to scale, pointing in the correct direction.
process_flow.mechanism: Use a ruler for length, protractor for angle.

process_flow.description: Start each new vector at the tip of the previous one, maintaining its own direction and scale.
Draw a straight arrow from the tail of the first vector to the tip of the last.
Measure its length (convert to magnitude using scale) and its angle (direction).

worked_examples.title: Adding Two Perpendicular Vectors Graphically
worked_examples.problem: Add vector $\vec{A} = 3\text{ m}$ east and $\vec{B} = 4\text{ m}$ north using the tip-to-tail method. Scale: 1 cm = 1 m.

step_by_step.explanation: Draw a 3 cm arrow pointing east (right).
Starting at the tip of $\vec{A}$, draw a 4 cm arrow pointing north (up).
Draw an arrow from the tail of $\vec{A}$ to the tip of $\vec{B}$.
Length = 5 cm → magnitude $5\text{ m}$. Angle from east = $\theta$ such that $\tan\theta = 4/3$ → $\theta \approx 53^\circ$.

worked_examples.final_answer: Resultant $\vec{R} = 5\text{ m}$ at $53^\circ$ north of east.

image.alt: Step-by-step illustration of tip-to-tail vector addition
image.caption: Tip-to-tail method: vectors are connected head to tail; resultant closes the polygon.

sections.introduction: For adding two vectors, the parallelogram method offers an alternative graphical technique.

key_concept.definition: To add two vectors using the parallelogram method, draw both vectors from the same starting point (tail together). Then complete a parallelogram: the resultant is the diagonal from the common tail to the opposite corner.
key_concept.context: This method is especially useful when visualizing the combined effect of two forces acting at a point, like two ropes pulling on an object.

process_flow.process: Draw both vectors from a common origin
process_flow.description: Place tails together at the same point, maintaining scale and direction.
process_flow.result: Two vectors emanating from one point.

process_flow.description: From the tip of each vector, draw a line parallel to the other vector.
The resultant is the diagonal from the common tail to the opposite corner.

worked_examples.title: Parallelogram Method for Two Forces
worked_examples.problem: Two forces act on a point: $\vec{F}_1 = 30\text{ N}$ east, $\vec{F}_2 = 40\text{ N}$ north. Use the parallelogram method to find the resultant. Scale: 1 cm = 10 N.

step_by_step.explanation: Draw a 3 cm arrow east, and a 4 cm arrow north from the same point.
From tip of east vector, draw a 4 cm line north (parallel to $\vec{F}_2$). From tip of north vector, draw a 3 cm line east (parallel to $\vec{F}_1$).
Draw arrow from origin to opposite corner.
Diagonal length = 5 cm → $50\text{ N}$. Angle from east = $\tan^{-1}(4/3) \approx 53^\circ$.

worked_examples.final_answer: Resultant $\vec{R} = 50\text{ N}$ at $53^\circ$ north of east.

image.alt: Diagram showing parallelogram method of vector addition
image.caption: Parallelogram method: vectors from common origin; diagonal is resultant.

sections.introduction: When vectors are perpendicular (at right angles), we can calculate the resultant exactly using the Pythagorean theorem and trigonometry.

key_concept.definition: For two perpendicular vectors $\vec{A}$ and $\vec{B}$, the magnitude of the resultant $\vec{R}$ is $R = \sqrt{A^2 + B^2}$, and its direction is given by $\theta = \tan^{-1}(B/A)$ measured from the direction of $\vec{A}$.
key_concept.context: This mathematical approach is faster and more precise than graphical methods, and it forms the basis for breaking vectors into components (covered later).

principles.statement: If $\vec{A}$ and $\vec{B}$ are perpendicular, the resultant magnitude is $R = \sqrt{A^2 + B^2}$.
principles.application: Treat the vectors as legs of a right triangle; the resultant is the hypotenuse.

principles.statement: The angle $\theta$ that the resultant makes with $\vec{A}$ satisfies $\tan\theta = \frac{B}{A}$.

worked_examples.title: Perpendicular Vectors Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A car travels 6 km east, then 8 km south. Find the displacement magnitude and direction.

step_by_step.explanation: $\vec{A} = 6\text{ km}$ east, $\vec{B} = 8\text{ km}$ south. They are perpendicular (east and south are 90° apart).
$\tan\theta = \frac{8}{6} = 1.333$, so $\theta = \tan^{-1}(1.333) \approx 53^\circ$ south of east (or $53^\circ$ east of south depending on reference).

worked_examples.final_answer: Displacement = $10\text{ km}$ at $53^\circ$ south of east.

image.alt: Right triangle formed by perpendicular vectors and resultant
image.caption: Perpendicular vectors add to form a right triangle; Pythagorean theorem gives resultant magnitude.

sections.introduction: Subtracting one vector from another is equivalent to adding its negative.

key_concept.definition: The difference $\vec{A} - \vec{B}$ is found by adding $\vec{A}$ and the negative of $\vec{B}$: $\vec{A} - \vec{B} = \vec{A} + (-\vec{B})$.
key_concept.context: Vector subtraction is useful for finding relative velocities, changes in velocity, and other differences where direction matters.

principles.statement: The negative of a vector has the same magnitude but opposite direction.
principles.application: To subtract $\vec{B}$, reverse its direction to get $-\vec{B}$, then add using tip-to-tail.
principles.example: If $\vec{B} = 5\text{ m}$ east, then $-\vec{B} = 5\text{ m}$ west.

worked_examples.title: Subtracting Vectors
worked_examples.problem: Given $\vec{A} = 10\text{ m}$ east and $\vec{B} = 4\text{ m}$ north, find $\vec{A} - \vec{B}$.

step_by_step.explanation: These are perpendicular: east and south.

image.alt: Diagram showing vector subtraction as addition of negative
image.caption: Vector subtraction: add the negative.

sections.introduction: Vector addition follows specific algebraic properties that are useful for manipulating equations.

key_concept.definition: Vector addition is commutative and associative, just like ordinary addition, but the geometric interpretation differs.
key_concept.context: These properties allow us to regroup vectors when adding more than two, simplifying calculations.

principles.application: Order doesn't matter; tip-to-tail in any order yields same resultant.
principles.example: 3 m east + 4 m north gives same resultant as 4 m north + 3 m east.

principles.application: When adding multiple vectors, grouping doesn't affect the final resultant.
principles.example: Adding three vectors: you can add first two, then third, or last two first, then first.

image.alt: Diagrams showing commutative and associative properties of vector addition
image.caption: Vector addition is commutative and associative.

sections.introduction: Even with clear methods, students often make predictable errors. Recognizing them helps ensure accuracy.

characteristics: Simply adding numbers without considering direction
classifications.behavior: Overestimates resultant magnitude unless vectors are in same direction.

examples.explanation: For 3 m east and 4 m north, saying resultant = 7 m (wrong).
Resultant = 5 m, calculated using Pythagorean theorem.

characteristics: Using the wrong angle in calculations
Confusing 'north of east' vs 'east of north'

examples.explanation: For $\tan^{-1}(4/3) \approx 53^\circ$, saying 53° east of north instead of north of east.

characteristics: Attempting to subtract vectors directly without direction reversal

key_terms.definition: The single vector that represents the sum of two or more vectors.
Graphical method of vector addition where vectors are placed sequentially head to tail.
Graphical method of adding two vectors by constructing a parallelogram and using the diagonal.
A vector with the same magnitude but opposite direction.

summary: Vector addition combines vectors to produce a resultant that accounts for both magnitude and direction. Graphically, the tip-to-tail method connects vectors sequentially; the resultant runs from the first tail to the last tip. The parallelogram method draws both vectors from a common origin, then uses the diagonal. For perpendicular vectors, the Pythagorean theorem gives resultant magnitude ($R = \sqrt{A^2 + B^2}$) and trigonometry gives direction ($\theta = \tan^{-1}(B/A)$). Vector subtraction is addition of a negative vector: $\vec{A} - \vec{B} = \vec{A} + (-\vec{B})$. Vector addition is commutative and associative, allowing flexible grouping. Common mistakes include adding magnitudes directly without regard to direction and misstating angles. Mastery of vector addition is essential for analyzing forces, velocities, displacements, and other vector quantities in physics.

practice_questions.question: Add the following vectors using the tip-to-tail method (describe the process): $\vec{A} = 5\text{ m}$ east, $\vec{B} = 3\text{ m}$ east.
practice_questions.answer: Draw $\vec{A}$ 5 units east. From its tip, draw $\vec{B}$ 3 units east. Resultant is 8 units east. (Magnitude 8 m, direction east.)

practice_questions.question: Two forces act on an object: 30 N north and 40 N east. Find the resultant force magnitude and direction.
What is $\vec{A} - \vec{B}$ if $\vec{A} = 12\text{ m}$ south and $\vec{B} = 5\text{ m}$ east?
practice_questions.answer: $-\vec{B} = 5\text{ m}$ west. Then $\vec{A} + (-\vec{B})$: south and west are perpendicular. $R = \sqrt{12^2 + 5^2} = \sqrt{144+25} = \sqrt{169} = 13\text{ m}$. Direction: $\tan\theta = 5/12 \approx 0.4167$, $\theta \approx 22.6^\circ$ west of south (or south of west?). Better: angle from south toward west.

practice_questions.question: Explain why the parallelogram method and tip-to-tail method give the same resultant.
practice_questions.answer: Both methods represent the same vector addition. In tip-to-tail, vectors are placed sequentially; in parallelogram, they are placed tail-to-tail and the diagonal completes the triangle. The diagonal of a parallelogram is equivalent to the vector from the tail of the first to the tip of the second when placed tip-to-tail.

practice_questions.question: Can the magnitude of the resultant ever be less than the magnitude of either original vector? Give an example.
practice_questions.answer: Yes, if the vectors point in opposite directions. For example, $\vec{A} = 10\text{ m}$ east, $\vec{B} = 6\text{ m}$ west. Resultant = $4\text{ m}$ east, which is less than $|\vec{A}|$.

practice_questions.question: Demonstrate the commutative property of vectors using a sketch.
practice_questions.answer: Draw $\vec{A}$ then $\vec{B}$ tip-to-tail; measure resultant. Then draw $\vec{B}$ then $\vec{A}$ tip-to-tail; the resultant should be the same vector (same length and direction).
